raw_text:
Blair prepares to name poll date
 
 Tony Blair is likely to name 5 May as election day when Parliament returns from its Easter break, the BBC's political editor has learned.
 
 Andrew Marr says Mr Blair will ask the Queen on 4 or 5 April to dissolve Parliament at the end of that week. Mr Blair has so far resisted calls for him to name the day but all parties have stepped up campaigning recently. Downing Street would not be drawn on the claim, saying election timing was a matter for the prime minister.
 
 A Number 10 spokeswoman would only say: "He will announce an election when he wants to announce an election." The move will signal a frantic week at Westminster as the government is likely to try to get key legislation through Parliament. The government needs its finance bill, covering the Budget plans, to be passed before the Commons closes for business at the end of the session on 7 April.
 
 But it will also seek to push through its Serious and Organised Crime Bill and ID cards Bill. Mr Marr said on Wednesday's Today programme: "There's almost nobody at a senior level inside the government or in Parliament itself who doesn't expect the election to be called on 4 or 5 April. "As soon as the Commons is back after the short Easter recess, Tony Blair whips up to the Palace, asks the Queen to dissolve Parliament ... and we're going." The Labour government officially has until June 2006 to hold general election, but in recent years governments have favoured four-year terms.
llama3.2:1b: Tony Blair will likely name poll date on May 5 or April 4, with all parties campaigning intensively for him to make the decision.
Downing Street is not commenting on the timing.
The government needs key legislation passed before it closes its session on April 7 and has announced plans to push through Bills such as the Finance Bill and ID cards Bill.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair is likely to name 5 May as the date for the upcoming election, with the government planning to get key legislation through Parliament before it closes on 7 April, and Blair will ask the Queen to dissolve Parliament on 4 or 5 April.

He will ask the Queen to dissolve Parliament at the end of April and all parties are currently campaigning actively.
The government plans to push for key legislation before the Commons closes on April 7th, including finance bill and Serious and Organised Crime Bill.

Downing Street would not be able to provide more details on the timing of an election call at that time.

He will seek the Queen's dissolution of Parliament around 4-5 April.
This move will require passing key legislation like the finance bill by the end of April, while also pushing through bills on serious and organized crime and ID cards.
Expectation is for the election to be held within a week of MPs returning from Easter recess.
The Labour government traditionally favours four-year terms, but this one may go ahead as planned in June 2006 or sooner.

tinyllama:1.1b:
Presenting key ideas and details from the given text, blair prepare to name poll date

Based on information obtained by Andrew Marr, Tony Blair is likely to name the day of the election in May when Parliament returns for a week-long break.
The prime minister has been resistant to calls for an early poll but all political parties have ramped up campaigning recently, with opposition parties calling for a referendum on the issue.
Downing Street refused to comment on whether the election date would be announced soon, stating that it was a matter of time for the prime minister to decide.
The government's legislative agenda will likely include the Financial Bill and ID card Bill, both expected to pass through Parliament before the Commons' break ends on April 7th.
However, there is still no guarantee that an election will be called as early as April 4 or 5th.

This event is expected to impact various pieces of legislation within the government, such as spending bills covering the Finance Bill and Serious and Organised Crime Bill, along with ID cards Bill.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Tony Blair is expected to announce a general election for 5 May, shortly after Parliament resumes from its Easter break, according to BBC's political editor Andrew Marr.
This decision follows intensified campaigning by all parties.
The government aims to pass crucial legislation, including the Budget bill and the Serious and Organised Crime Bill, before the Commons closes at the end of the session on 7 April.
Despite the government's official deadline for elections being June 2006, recent trends favor four-year terms, making a May date more likely.

The prime minister will formally request the Queen to dissolve Parliament during his visit to the Palace in early April, marking a busy week at Westminster as the government rushes to complete legislative business before the election call.
Downing Street declined to comment on this speculation, stating that election timing is the prime minister's prerogative.
